data: Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Manganaro, 1988, La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano
Belvedere, 1988, Opere pubbliche ed effici per lo spettacolo nella Sicilia di eta imperiale
Wilson, 1988, Towns of Sicily during the Roman Empire
Wilson, 1990, Sicily under the Roman Empire: the archaeology of a Roman province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535
Inscribed base of a dedication to Venus Victrix

A Latin text over 10 lines, engraved on the narrow front face
                                        of the base. The engraved face is 8 cm wide by 27.7 cm high.
                                        The majority of the words are run over onto the following
                                        line, with the final letters centred, suggesting that the
                                        visual effect was prioritised over the sense of the words.
                                        The text is large and well spaced in the upper part,
                                        becoming compressed towards the end, with the final lines
                                        overlapping.

Deeply, but rather irregularly cut letters.
                                    Y and T are tall, as is I in line 4; R is closed. Interpuncts in
                                    the form of a comma.
Korhonen suggests a date between the second half of the first and the end of the 2nd century CE
Photograph of front face by students of  Liceo M.M. Lazzaro
Pace, 1945, Arte e Civiltà della Sicilia antica. Volume terzo. Cultura e vita religiosa
Manganaro, 1964, Città di Sicilia e santuarii panellenici nel III e II secolo a.c.
Manganaro, 1977, Per la storia dei culti nella Sicilia greca
Manganaro, 1996, Per una storia della chora Katania
Manganaro, 2000, Hybla Megala (Heraia) e Hybla Geleatis (Etnea)
Trotta, 2000, I culti dell Sicilia: tra Greci e Iblei
inscribed base of a dedication to venus victrix
Dedication to the Genius of the city of Catania

The text is preserved intact, over seven lines, although the edge
                                        of the surviving stone clips the tops of the letters of the first line. The
                                        letters diminish in size over the first four lines, with a vacat in the second
                                        half of line four; the final three lines are larger again. The left margin of
                                        the text is maintained regularly, the right margin varies from line to line.

The letters are deeply but somewhat irregularly cut, with some
                                    internal variation (e.g. A appears with both broken and straight bar; E appears both
                                    as a tall narrow standard E and as a vertical stroke with a single horizontal bar
                                    across the middle; V appears both as V and as Y). Interpuncts are mostly absent,
                                    except after VC and CONS in the final two lines.

Munatidius is not otherwise known; the mention of three Domini
                                    requires one of the periods 337—340, 367—378, 379—383, 388—395, 402—408, and 421. A
                                    precise choice is not possible, but the consensus amongst scholars is for a date in
                                    the 4th century rather than later.
Photograph of front face by J. Prag
L'année épigraphique: revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l'antiquité romaine., 1888-
Manganaro, 1958-1959, Iscrizioni latine e greche di Catania tardo-imperiale
Manganaro, 1993, Greco nei pagi e latino nelle città della Sicilia romana tra I e VI sec. d.C.
dedication to the genius of the city of catania
Inscription recording restoration of a nymphaeum

The form of the letter P is distinctive (found also in the letter of
                                    Iulius Paternus, ISic000308) with a horizontal stroke at the base.

inscription recording restoration of a nymphaeum

Second half of 1st century or first
                                half of 2nd century CE (Korhonen)

Eck, 1996, Senatorische familien der kaiserzeit in der provinz Sizilien

First half of 4th century CE (so
                                Korhonen on letters and titles)

1st century CE or beginning of 2nd century CE (Korhonen)
Asheri, 1982-1983, Le città della Sicilia fra il III e IV secolo d.C.
funerary altar for quintus atilius severus, duumvir of catania
Letter of Iulius Paternus to the Emperors Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus

Latin text preserved over 12 lines. The first line is in slightly larger and more widely spaced letters. The text closes up over lines 2 and 3, 
                                    with a more or less regular size and spacing over the rest of the stone. Interpuncts are used sparingly in the text, and their placing appears 
                                    deliberately intended to emphasise certain elements. The letters are neatly cut, with limited serifs (but sometimes substantial feet to vertical strokes), 
                                    and a tendency towards the taller narrower letters common from the second/third centuries AD onwards; this is particularly noticeable with 
                                    the letter E, which is not always easy to distinguish when corroded. Tall 'I' is employed. P is generally open.
164—166 CE, on basis of restoration of first word as Armeniacis when Aurelius and Verus both held this title
letter of iulius paternus to the emperors marcus aurelius and lucius verus
List of magistrates of Catania from years 268—9 CE (prob., so manganaro, followed by K)
Inscribed statue base for Lucius Rubrius Proculus
Four lines of Latin text, centred on the stone and filling the face, slightly decreasing in size from line 1.

Large, plain, deeply cut letters. P is open, R and B are closed; some upright strokes (all letter I, some L and V) have a serif ascending upper right; plain interpuncts in lines 1 and 3; the numeral in line 3 is marked by a mid-bar.
Lettering and absence of filiation suggest a 2nd century CE date (Korhonen)
Castelli, 1769, Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio
Ferrara, 1829, Storia di Catania sino alla fine del secolo XVIII
Libertini, 1937, Il Castello Ursino e le raccolte artistiche comunali di Catania
Mole Ventura, 1996, Catania in età imperiale
inscribed statue base for lucius rubrius proculus
Fragmentary inscription of a civic magistrate
Beginning of two lines of Latin letters, set within the moulding. Red paint is preserved in some of the letters.

Neat, elegant letters in a thin v-cut; both lines are broken off and
                                    incomplete.
1st century CE, or beginning 2nd century CE (so Korhonen)
fragmentary inscription of a civic magistrate
Fragment of an inscription for a civic magistrate

Beginning of two lines of Latin letters; the space below line 2
                                        at 58-62mm leaves open the possibility of letters below.

Regular letters engraved in a neat, wide v-cut, with light serifs.
                                    Interpunct formed by a dot, supraline above numerals.
1st century CE, or beginning 2nd century CE (Korhonen)
fragment of an inscription for a civic magistrate
'Second or third quarter of the 4th century CE' (Wilson, 1990, p.187, fig.156)
Each word is placed in a tabula ansata, held in the hands of a pair of facing small naked male figures
The text appears to have maintained a consistent left margin, rather than being centred upon the stone; seven lines of Latin with an irregular right margin.
End 1st century CE or 2nd century CE (so Korhonen)
Photo by students of Liceo Lazzaro, courtesy Museo Civico di Catania
Rizzo, 1989, La menzione del lavoro nelle epigrafi della Sicilia antica: per una storia della mentalità
Cassia, 2018, L’estranea «di famiglia»: una nutrix in un’epigrafe catanese d’età imperiale
Funerary inscription for Aphrodito, a mime actress

Latin text over six lines, roughly centred on the plaque. Lines
                                    1-3 are more widely spaced and better centred; lines 4-6 are more compressed in
                                    the lower right.

Letters show some tendency to a cursive style, but the name in line 2
                                    is notably marked out in a more classical majuscule style. One instance of ligature
                                    in line 6. Use of simple hedera as interpuncts in lines 3-6.
2nd century CE or beginning of 3rd century CE
Photograph by Liceo Artistico Statale "M. M. Lazzaro" di Catania
funerary inscription for aphrodito, a mime actress

The first two lines of a Latin text are preserved, within the
                                        frame created by the moulding.

Neat, regular Letters engraved in a deep, wide v-cut, and refined
                                    interpuncts. The letters have a brown paint within them. Line 2 is only partly
                                    preserved, at least 35mm high.
1st century CE or beginning 2nd century CE (Korhonen)
Korhonen, 2004, La cultura epigrafica della colonia di Catina nell'alto impero
Funerary inscription for Lucius Cassius Hermes

Latin text over seven lines. Line 1 is centred, lines 2-7
                                        maintain the left margin. There is some compression of the letters lower right.

Letters show a cursive tendency. The foot of P, T, I extends notably
                                    to the right; F and R have trailing lower strokes. Simple interpuncts between words.
funerary inscription for lucius cassius hermes

Second half of 2nd century CE or first
                                half of 3rd century CE (K)

Second half of 1st century CE or 2nd century CE
                                (K)
Bilingual funerary inscription for Quintus Domitius
Probably 1st century BCE, or early 1st century CE

                                (Korhonen)

Pensabene, 1996-1997, Edilizia pubblica e committenza marmi e officine in Italia meridionale e Sicilia durante il II e III secolo d.C.

First three
                                quarters of 1st century CE (K)
Remains of two lines of Latin letters across the stone, with traces of a third line in Greek below

Thinly incised letters with terminal points/serifs to the strokes. Greek letters are much smaller than Latin letters. The M tends lightly towards the cursive form, and some letters join at the foot; A in the Latin text has an upward sloping cross-bar; Greek text appears to have lunate epsilon.
1st century or beginning of 2nd century CE (Korhonen)
Photo J. Prag courtesy Museo Civico di Catania
Epitaph of Caius Pompeius Felix and Scribonia Restituta
Three lines of Latin letters, decreasing in height, and seemingly centred on the plaque.
Broad, square letter modules, in a wide V-cut with basic serifs, and triangular interpuncts.
1st century CE (Korhonen, by lettering and (lack of) formula)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 13.05.2016
epitaph of caius pompeius felix and scribonia restituta
Four lines of Latin text, with line 1 not exactly centred (left of centre), and a roughly uniform left margin lines for lines 2-4. Line 1 is larger. The text is heavily repainted with a brown paint.
Second half of 1st century CE or 2nd century CE (Korhonen)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J.Prag 14.10.2016
End 1st century CE or 2nd century CE (K)

2nd century CE or beginning 3rd century CE
                                (K)
Four lines of Latin text, centred on the upper half of the plaque.

Irregular letters, with M and N cursive in form. Interpuncts in lines
                                    1 and 3.
Second half of 2nd century CE or 3rd century CE (so Korhonen)
The letters are written in a fluid cursive style which recalls painted letters (good examples at Pompeii).
Second half of 1st — first half of 3rd century CE (K)
Three lines of Latin letters preserved, of decreasing size.
Triangular interpunct in line three. Brown paint in the letters.
1st century CE or early 2nd century CE (K)

I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana (Photo by students of Liceo Lazzaro, 2017)
Ferrua, 1982-1983, Le iscrizioni datate della Sicilia paleocristiana
Ferrua, 1989, Note e giunte alle iscrizioni cristiane antiche della Sicilia
Inscribed base of statue group of the Pii Fratres

Latin text preserved over six lines. Despite the extensive damage
                                        around the edges, almost all of the text appears to be preserved, with only a
                                        few letters lost from the right margin and at the top corners.

The letters show characteristic features of the more cursive style of
                                    late antiquity, with V having the large rounded U form.

The inscription cannot be later than the end of the 5th century,
                                    due to the archaeological evidence for the cessation of use of the theatre by that
                                    date
Mazzarino, 1956, "Spectabilis Consularis provinciae Siciliae" (A proposito di una nuova epigrafe catanese)
inscribed base of statue group of the pii fratres
Regular letters with apices: Ε, Σ have square form (square-bottomed cursive Ω), Ξ is cursive.
Manganaro, 1994, Iscrizioni, epigrafi ed epigrammi in Greco della Sicilia orientale di epoca romana
Verse inscription recording building of a nymphaeum

3rd or possibly early 4rth century CE. Perhaps middle/later
                                    4th century CE
Kaibel, 1878, Epigrammata graeca ex lapidibus conlecta
Peek, 1955, Griechische Vers-Inschriften. Bd. 1, Grab - Epigramme
verse inscription recording building of a nymphaeum

Elongated letters with apices: Α with a straight cross-bar at l. 2 and l. 4, an upward sloping cross-bar at l. 3, Ε has a squared form, Θ, Ο, Ω an angled form, Φ has an extended upright and an angular bowl.
1st century CE or early 2nd century CE
Funerary inscription of Gaius Iulius Eutychus
Second half of 1st century — 2nd century CE
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2017-07-01
funerary inscription of gaius iulius eutychus
The text is laid out over ten very short lines, respecting word breaks until the final lines.
End of 1st century CE or 2nd century CE (Korhonen)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo Liceo Lazzaro, 2018

Irregular letters, some of which are larger than the others (the Latin D, the Greek Β). In the Greek text, E, Θ (according to Ferrua's drawing), Ω are lunate, (Latin and Greek), A has a broken cross-bar, Ξ is cursive. 
                                From Ferrua's drawing, the abbreviation of ὑπατίᾳ is realized through a small superscript π above the υ.
The Greek inscription has the consular date of 455 CE. If, as Manganaro believes, the two inscriptions are not the Latin and the Greek version of the same epitaph, they are nevertheless contemporary.

A single line of Hebrew is followed by 14 lines of Latin; the Latin text observes a more or less regular left margin, irregular on the right. The lower right and left corners contain small incised menorahs, with the last line of text between them consisting simply of 'overspill' from the preceding line, offset towards the right.

Letters generally neatly and regularly cut, with basic serifs on the long strokes. B is somewhat irregular in fomration, sometimes with equal loops, sometimes with smaller upper loop; C is large and open; E is narrow, with three short equal horizontal strokes; G has distinctive form of small C with a tail descending to lower right; M is formed of four equal diagonal strokes; P has a somewhat elongated frequently (but not always) closed loop, but some instances have a wide horizaontal foot also; Q is closed with a trailing tail;  R is usually closed, with a tail usually straight and extended but finishing above the line; S is frequently oversize. The two menorahs at the foot of the inscription are 15 mm and 23 mm (the left is incomplete).
Photo by students of Liceo Lazzaro, 2017-05-11
Libertini, 1929, Epigrafe giudaico-latina rinvenuta in Catania
Noy, 1993, Jewish inscriptions of Western Europe
Grüll, 2000, " Conquerors, Patriarchs and the Law of the Lord". Interpretation of a late antique Jewish epitaph
Manganaro, 2004-2005, Giudei grecanici nella Sicilia di eta imperale (documentazione epigrafica e figurativa)
Giuffrida, 2020, Aurelius Samohil between ius and identity
1st — 2nd century CE (Manganaro, on absence of praenomen)
Agnello, 1953, Silloge di iscrizioni paleocristiane della Sicilia
six lines of Greek letters with a consistent left margin, and a slight gap between lines 1-3 and lines 4-6.
Simply cut letters without serifs. Quadrate epsilon, lunate quadrate sigma, rhomboid omega, mu with very short middle strokes. Use of stigma in numerals, and interpuncts to separate numerals.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo Liceo Lazzaro 2018-01-08
Muscolino, 2011-2012, Epigrafi funerarie greche e latine di Taormina
Lines 1-4 are more centred, and there is a space between lines 4 and 5.
A with an upward sloping cross-bar, Ε, Σ, Ω lunate. Traces of guidelines.
Edict of Flavius Felix Eumathus regarding the Thermae Achillianae

Greek text over four lines. The fourth line is shorter than the
                                        other three and ends with a vacat. The letters are broadly regular and neatly
                                        cut, but the sizing and spacing varies considerably across the four lines.

Letters are wide and omicron, phi, sigma, epsilon and theta are, on
                                    occasion formed by overlarge circles. Epsilon, sigma and omega are lunate. Xsi is
                                    formed in a distinctive, ornate fashion. Interpuncts are used occasionally, and
                                    formed of an 's' shape, sometimes forward, sometimes backward facing. Numerals are
                                    marked with a supraline.
434 CE (reporting an edict from the consuls of 433)
edict of flavius felix eumathus regarding the thermae achillianae

Alpha has broken bar; epsilon has a squared form, with all bars of equal length, although the middle bar does not always join the vertical; theta a large circle, the middle bar does not extend to the edges; the width of N is variable (at l. 1); mu has four full length strokes, the first and last vertical; rho has a small curved head; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; omega has a straight horizontal bar and a teardrop-shaped body. The carver consistently left a space between words.
Remains of four lines of an incomplete Greek text centred on the stone

Moderately regularly and deeply incised letters with pronounced terminal points but without substantial serifs. Broken bar Α, lunate Σ and Ε. Occasional use of hederae between words. Line lower right may be remains of a supraline above a numeral, or else an ornate hedera.
Second half of 1st century CE or 2nd century CE
Blocks from a monumental Greek text
It is unclear without further study whether the letters were incised after firing (as Korhonen suggests), or actually moulded prior to firing (as their form would appear to suggest).
later third to early first century BCE
Benndorf, Schöne, 1867, Die antiken Bildwerke des Lateranensischen Museums
blocks from a monumental greek text
Korhonen, 2001, Osservazioni sul collezionismo epigrafico siciliano

Letters irregularly incised, slighltly decreasing in size: A with a broken cross-bar; rhomboid Θ, Ο, Φ (this last letter with an elongated upright), squared and lunate Ε, quadrate lunate Σ, lunate Ω. Use of hederae at l. 1 between the nomen and the cognomen of the deceased (and, according to Amico's drawing, also at l. 3 after ΛΙΑ)
3rd century CE or beginning 4th century CE (Korhonen)
Torremuzza, 1769, Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio
Torremuzza, 1784, Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio prolegomenis et notis illustrata, et iterum cum emendationibus, & auctariis evulgata
Regular letters with extensions and serifs, Ε, Σ lunate, Μ a cursive form (narrowed Σ at the end of l. 2 and l. 6), ΗΣ are in ligature at l. 6.
Regular letters with serifs, slightly decreasing in size, rhomboid Ο, squared Ε.
Ferrua, 1941, Epigrafica sicula pagana e cristiana
Irregular letters: rhomboid Θ, Ο and Ω, angular Μ, ΤΗ in ligature at l. 5. Presence of two ivy leaves at the beginning and at the end of l. 6 (the last one seen by Kaibel)
2nd century CE or first half of 3rd century CE
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo Liceo Lazzaro 10.01.2018
Lunate Ε, Θ, Σ, cursive Μ, Φ with a long vertical stroke, ΝΗ in ligature. Occasional presence of interpuncts (triangular).

Letters with serifs: lunate Ε, Θ, Σ, Α and Λ with a slightly curved right side (and A with a curved or broken bar). Presence of an ivy leaf between Θ and Κ at l. 1 and of a triangle-shaped interpunct between ἔζησε and ἔτη at l. 5.
Second half of 1st — first half of 2nd century CE (Korhonen)
Cassia, 2020, “La stola e il silenzio”? “Parole” di donna in un epitaffio catanese d’età imperiale
Rhomboid Ο, Θ, Φ; Α with broken bar. Presence of interpuncts and of a ligature of ΜΗ at l. 3
1st — 2nd century CE ('La datazione è difficile', Korhonen 2004: 214)
Rhomboid Ο. The letters at l. 3 are slightly larger and more spaced out than the other lines.
From the second half of the 1st cent. to the end of the 2nd cent.  CE(Korhonen)

Regular letters: rhomboid Θ, Ο, Ω (open); Α with accentuated upper serif, Μ with slanting full-length bars (but irregular), Υ with an extended right arm (line 6), ΗΝΕ at l. 4 and ΤΗ at l. 5 (x2) in ligature. In the last line, some letters are smaller than others for lack of space.
Second half of 1st — end 2nd century CE
Spuches, 1864, Illustrazione d'alcune epigrafi e d'altri oggetti archeologici
Photo by students of Liceo M.M. Lazzaro, Catania
Letters with serifs, rhomboid Ο, rounded open Ω , Ξ is a Z with a horizontal bar.
1st century CE or first half of 2nd century CE
Regular letters, Α with upper serif, lunate Ε and Σ, Κ with arms detached from the upright.
1st century — first half of 2nd century CE
“Scrittura corsiveggiante alla latina” (Korhonen). Lunate Ε (at l. 5, but quadrate at l. 4) and Σ, cursive Ω. Α, Λ and Μ with serifs, Κ with short arms. Open triangle-shaped interpunct at l. 3.
Bertucci, 1846, Guida del Monastero dei PP. Benedettini di Catania

Α with a broken bar, lunate Ε and Σ, cursive M (at l. 2) and Ω, Ψ with a long upright. The cross bar of Η is formed decoratively. Interpuncts at ll. 1, 3 and 4, two ivy leaves at l. 4. Letters at ll. 4 and 5 are slightly larger and separated from the others by a larger space.

Irregular letters with serifs: Α with broken bar, lunate Ε and Σ, rhomboid Θ, Κ with long and curved upright, short arms, Μ with five slanting lines at l. 4, Ρ with the bottom of the eye left open, extended/tall iota. Ivy leaves at ll. 1, 3, 4 and 5, vertical bar between Γαμική and ἀνδρί at l. 6.
Letters with serifs, rhomboid Ο and Φ, angular cursive Ω at l. 5 (as a flipped Μ); ος at l. 2, τη at l. 3, ος and ρων at l. 5 in ligature. Triangle-shaped interpuncts at ll. 3, 4, 5, 6.
Lines 1, 4 and 7 are set further to the left, with the other lines indented by one character space, reflecting the beginning of each line of hexameter verse.
Regular letters: lunate Ε, Σ, cursive Ω, Α with broken bar.
Late 3rd — late 4th century CE (Korhonen on the basis of lettering)

I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo students of Liceo Lazzaro, 12.01.2018
Molè Ventura, 2018, "De' pii l'inclita città..." Identità civica e processi di acculturazione a Catania tra ellenismo e tarda antichità
Regular letters: lunate Ε, Σ, cursive Μ. Φ with an extended upright and Υ at l. 4 with extended slanted bars.
Second half of 1st century — first half of 2nd century CE
Letters with serifs: Ε and Σ lunate, Η at l. 2 in smaller size.
Θ in a simple form, with a straight and attached cross-bar, squared lunate Σ and squared cursive Ω.
Cursive Μ, Ο in smaller size; lunate epsilon according to Kaibel. The second line is indented.
Second half of 3rd century CE or 4th century CE
Regular letters, Ε and Σ lunate, Μ cursive.
Letters with serifs: Ε and Σ lunate, Μ cursive.
Regular letters, Ε and Σ lunate.
Irregular letters: lunate Ε and Σ, cursive Μ and Ω. Α, Δ and Λ with accentuated upper serifs. Chi-Rho symbol in the middle of l. 6.

The text is set out over nine lines, complete apart from the very
                                        ends of lines 9 and 10. Chi-rho symbols are set to the left of line two and the
                                        right of line three, and a star is set in the middle between lines one and two.
                                        There is some crowding in the final two lines. The text is approximately centred
                                        on the disc and the crowding at the end of line 8 in particular suggests that
                                        the stone was cut to this circular shape prior to engraving.

The letters are neatly but irregularly cut. Lunate epsilon, sigma and
                                    omega; alpha has a steeply left sloping cross-bar, the right hasta extended well
                                    above the rest of the letter; beta is tall, with two closed eyes, separated from
                                    each other. Supralinear lines are used above numerals and also in line 6.
Funerary inscription for Adrianos and Deuteria
funerary inscription for adrianos and deuteria
The remains of one line of Greek letters, preceded by a plain cross (which may be a later addition), are preserved on the moulding at the base of the relief.

Slightly irregularly disposed letters, with a hedera between the first two words. In the text preserved by Gualtherus lunate epsilon, sigma and cursive omega are recorded, and interpuncts before the numerals.
Later 2nd century CE or first half of 3rd century CE
Epitaph for Aurelios Restoutos and Zosime
Irregular letters: lunate Ε and Σ; cursive Μ and Ω; Α and Λ with extended serifs.
4th century CE or first half of 5th century CE
epitaph for aurelios restoutos and zosime
Chi-Rho symbol at l. 1. Lunate Ε and Σ; cursive Ξ and Ω; A with slanted bar; Υ is similar to the Latin V.
Irregular letters, Α and Δ with serifs; quadrate Ε; nearly rhomboid O at l. 2.
Ferrua, 1938, Osservazioni sulle iscrizioni cristiane catanesi
Funerary inscription for Kallistos and Eukarpia
Paint in the lettters, but probably modern, and at least one letter (end of line 1) is omitted in the painting, as is sigma in ligature in line 2.
rhomboid omicron and omega; Tau is consistently tall than other letters.
funerary inscription for kallistos and eukarpia
Quadrate Ε, square lunate Σ, cursive Ω. Two Christograms with the letters A and Σ at start and end of inscription and a dove holding a twig below.
Letters with serifs: Α with broken bar, quadrate Ε, square lunate Σ, rhomboid Θ, cursive Ω (Ω at l. 5 as a Μ upside down). Letters at ll. 1-2 are slightly larger than letters in the following lines.

funerary inscription for leontia and kalliope
Irregular letters: angular Ε, lunate Σ, cursive Ω. A with a slanted bar (except at l. 1 where the bar is straight), Υ with the form of the Latin V. Interpuncts divide numerals from words.
Angular Ε and Σ, cursive Ω, Α, Δ, Λ with extended serifs, Chi-Rho symbol at the end of the inscription.

Lunate Ε (oft confused with Σ) and Σ, cursive Μ and Ω, A with straight bar (l. 1) and broken bar (l. 5). A vertical stroke divides ἔτη from the numeral. Presence of guide-lines, a Christogram and a cross.
Alessi, 1833, III. Giuseppe Alessi al chiarissimo segretario dell'instituto archeologico, salute.
Letters with apices, lunate Ε and Σ, cursive Ω, A with slanted bar.

Regular letters, lunate Ε, cursive Ω, A and Δ with extended serifs.

Funerary inscription for Jason the Elder
Eight lines of Greek filling the face, with the final line only made up of the last two letters. Double guidelines between lines 2-3 and 4-5, single guidelines above line 1 and line 7.
Some terminations to strokes/heavy serifs, but mostly serif free. Lunate epsilon and sigma, cursive omega. Letters somewhat irregular in size and placement.

Deeply cut letters (although the surface is worn) of moderately regular form, with a consistent left margin, over three lines.

Letters are broadly regular, in broad rounded strokes without serifs. Omicron is small and mid-line; sigma is lunate, but epsilon is of regular straight form; the eye of the phi is rhomboid; kappa has short arms; alpha has straight bar.

Relatively tall letters with modest serfis/terminations to the strokes. Rho is open; Sigma is four-bar, with very shallow middle strokes; Mu has all four strokes oblique, with the middle strokes only half-height.

Greek text over four lines, centred in the main panel of the
                                        tabula ansata on the front face of the urn.

Neat and regular square letters. Phi and omicron are rhomboid in
                                    form; standard four-bar sigma; epsilon has horizontal bars of equal length; alpha
                                    has a slightly extended apex; mu has extended apices, and all four strokes are full
                                    length and off-vertical. There is one instance of ligature in line 3, and
                                    interpuncts are in the form of simple triangular incisions.
69 CE — first half of 2nd century CE

Irregular letters, cursive A, Μ and Ω, lunate Ε and Σ.

A with broken bar, squared E (except at l. 3 where it is lunate), lunate Σ, cursive Ω. At ll. 2 and 4, Π and Τ are crossed by slanting bars, which could indicate an abbreviation. Small H and Ο above Τ and Π at l. 4, small curved signs at the upper right of T at l. 2, T and Ν at l. 4. Small curved signs below Υ and inside Ω and Α at l. 2, which could be now decoration marks, now abbreviation marks.
A with broken bar, Δ with serif, lunate Ε and Σ, cursive Ω.
A with broken bar, lunate Ε and Σ, curved Υ, Φ with a small bowl and extended upright.
A with broken bar, lunate Ε and Σ.
Letters with apices, Ν with the oblique that does not start and end from the top of one upright to the bottom of the other upright, lunate Σ. At l. 1 the cross has been erased.
Letters with apices, A with broken bar, lunate Ε and Σ, cursive Μ and Ω. Two Christograms at l. 7.
